attributes.title: Heuristics about African Americans as Unique Predictors of Context-Level Implicit Racial Bias
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

dataCollectionDates.value: -	The proposal process started at the end of the Spring 2019 semester, with the proposal occurring December 2019. March 27th is the no risk deadline for thesis submission, so this set of analyses will be completed by that date. However, any additional analyses (for publication or other means) might take place over the summer 2020.

question2a.value:
-	These variables will be treated as IVs in our regression equation. All will be aggregated to the context-level (both MSAs and counties) such that individual is no longer the unit of analysis (see details in anticipated transformations).
-	Skin Tone IAT is a between context variable, aggregated such that we are looking between geographic areas. 
-	Weapons IAT is a between context variable, aggregated such that we are looking between geographic areas. 
-	Economic Disadvantage is created from Population Size, Unemployment Rate by Race, Poverty Rate by Race. These are also between context variables, aggregated such that we are looking between geographic areas.

question2b.value: Race IAT is a between participant variable, aggregated such that we are looking between geographic areas.

question10b.value:
Implicit association test. The IAT (Greenwald, McGhee, & Schwartz, 1998) is a computer-based reaction time test that provides information about the strength of associations between sets of social categories and evaluative or stereotypic concepts. All IATs have seven blocks but vary in what concepts they measure.
o	The first two blocks allow participants to practice using the “E” and “I” key to sort the two types of stimuli. The first block sorts the two social groups on two different sides of the screen. The second block teaches participants to sort the evaluative or stereotypic words on two different sides of the screen.
o	The third and fourth block combine the two pairs of concepts such that participants are matching one social group and one concept to the left side of the screen and the other combination of social group and concept to the right side of the screen. For example, in the Race IAT, participants might be asked to sort both “White” and “Good” stimuli on the right using the “I” key as well as sort both “Black” and “Bad” stimuli on the left using the “E” key. Block three includes 20 trials and block four includes 40 trials.
o	The fifth block is a training block where participants then practice switching the concepts, such that the word or picture on the right side of the screen is now being matched with the social category that was previously on the left side of the screen. The side associated with the racial categories changes such that “White” would now be sorted on the left side with the “E” key and “Black” would now be sorted on the right side with the “I” key. Participants are only sorting the social group in the fifth block to get used to the change in categorization.
o	The sixth and seventh block again combined the two pairs of concepts, but the opposite pairings are opposite to those of block three and four. For example, “White” would still be sorted on the left and “Black” would still be sorted on the right as well as sorting “Bad” on the left with the “E” key and sorting “Good” on the right with the “I” key. Block six includes 20 trials and block seven includes 40 trials.
o	Participant’s scores (called an IATD score) is calculated as the difference in reaction time between two pairings, divided by the standard deviation of the response latencies for these two blocks. In the Race IAT, this would be the degree to which participants more quickly pair “White” with “Good” than they pair “Black” with “Good”. Whether the first pairing is congruent (“White” and “Good”) or incongruent (“Black” and “Good”) is randomized between participants. It is important to recognize that the IAT captures two different sets of associations: associations about Black Americans and the associations about White Americans. While these might be independent, they are deeply connected. Indeed, many studies conceptualize prejudice as a preference for one group compared to a dispreference for the other group (Alter, Stern, Granot, & Balcetis, 2016). 
o	This study will be using the Race IAT, Weapons IAT, and Skin Tone IAT. Data will be downloaded from the Open Science Framework (Xu, Nosek, & Greenwald, 2014). All of the stimuli used for these IATs are available online (https://www.projectimplicit.net/nosek/stimuli/). 

Race IAT. The Race IAT compares the speed at which participants pair Black versus White faces with “Good” versus “Bad” words. This task typically shows a preference for White over Black faces.

Skin tone IAT. The Skin Tone IAT compares the speed at which the participants pair dark-skinned and light-skinned drawings of faces with “Good” and “Bad” words. This task typically shows a preference for light-skinned over dark-skinned faces.

Weapons IAT. The Weapons IAT compares the speed at which the participants pair Black versus White faces with weapons and harmless objects. This task typically shows an automatic association for Black Americans with weapons than harmless objects.

Economic disadvantage. Economic disadvantage at the MSA and county level will be assessed using multiple variables. 
o	Unemployment disparity. We will calculate relative rate of unemployment for each county and MSA from appropriate Census Data (U.S. Census Bureau, 2017b). We will first calculate the employment rate for each race in each area by dividing number of white citizens unemployed by the number of white citizens in that area and will repeat this process for Whites and Blacks for all counties and MSAs of interest. We will then divide the percentage of white citizens unemployed by the percentage of Black citizens unemployed to compute unemployment disparity.
o	Poverty disparity. The poverty rate will be taken from the Census Bureau (U.S. Census Bureau, 2017b). This measure includes people that are just above the poverty line, representing people with an income below the established poverty level for their state and family size. We will calculate relative rate of poverty for each county and MSA from appropriate Census Data (U.S. Census Bureau, 2017b). We will first calculate the poverty rate for each race in each area by dividing number of white citizens in below the poverty line by the number of white citizens in that area and will repeat this process for Whites and Blacks for all counties and MSAs of interest. We will then divide the percentage of white citizens under the poverty line by the percentage of Black citizens under the poverty line to compute poverty disparity.

Covariates. Including a few covariates will allow us to control for potential confounds. We will include two context-level covariates (median income and crime rate).	
o	Median income. Median income will be taken from the Census Bureau (U.S. Census Bureau, 2017a). The national median income of about $62,000 in 2018 (Guzman, 2019).
o	Crime rate. Crime rate will be calculated using the number of violent crimes as reported by the FBI Uniform Crime Reporting Program and Census Bureau (Federal Bureau of Investigation – Uniform Crime Reporting [FBI – UCR] 2015a, 2016; U.S. Census Bureau, 2017c). Included in the FBI’s calculation of violent crime are four offenses: murder and nonnegligent manslaughter, rape, robbery, and aggravated assault (FBI-UCR, 2015b). Crime rate will then be calculated by dividing the number of crimes committed in an area by the population of that area. Population estimates are calculated as part of the American Community Survey (ACS) for counties and MSAs (US Census Bureau, 2017c). Using FBI UCR and ACS data, we need to calculate the violent crime rate for each county and MSA of interest. We will divide the number of violent crimes by the number of people in each area. This will be calculated for each area of interest.

question4b.value: -	Since this is all archival data, we do not control the pre-selection rules. While there are barriers (such as internet access) and incentives (such as understanding your bias) that might attract different people to the IAT, there are no explicit pre-selection rule. The same applies for the census and FBI UCR.

question5b.value:
-	IAT data will be collected from Project Implicit. 
-	Violent crime rate will be collected from FBI UCR.
-	Median income and components of economic disadvantage will be collected from the Census.

question6b.value:
-	The aggregation cut off of 25 comes from previous studies within our lab that suggest 25 produces a stable estimate and maximizes variability (Denzler, Regal, Gorenstein, Lim, & Devos, 2020). 
-	We are requiring each geographical area (both counties and MSAs) to have a minimum of 25 participants to ensure reliability of scores and validity of scores.
-	As far as number of counties or MSAs, this is determined indirectly by the aggregation process.

question7b.value: Since we are using all archival data, no data collection termination rule is necessary.

question8b.value:
-	For all three IATs, we will use data from 2004 to 2018 aggregated across years to estimate IATD scores for an area (both county and Metropolitan Statistical Area). 
-	We consolidate to a list of MSAs and counties that have at least 25 respondents for each IAT.
-	Data from other sources (census and FBI UCR) will be matched to MSAs and counties in which we have at least 25 participants. 
-	Due to the flexibility allotted to participants, there are a variety of standard exclusion criteria used to minimize noise from a variety of sources. 

-	a) Participants missing geographic data will also be removed. Only data from United States metropolitan areas will be analyzed. We consolidate to a list of MSAs and counties that have at least 25 respondents for each IAT. Data from other sources (census and FBI UCR) will be matched to MSAs and counties in which we have at least 25 participants. 
-	b) no manipulation checks or suspicion probes
-	c) No participants are removed for demographic reasons. Suspicious demographic information (age 107) is included. 
-	d) none?
-	e) Participants with 10% of their response times being faster than 300 milliseconds will be removed to improve the quality of the data; we assume that those with too many quick responses are not attending to the task at hand.

question9b.value:
-	There is typically a large proportion of participants that have invalid/missing IAT scores and missing geographic data. Dropping more than 10% of participants for methodological reasons (i.e. for reasons other than missing data) would be cause for reconsideration.
-	We usually do not place a strict cut off on the percentage of areas covered by look at their geographic coverage. If coverage is an issue (which happens infrequently), it can be discussed as a limitation. This study is a Master's thesis, so a small geographic coverage will not hinder completion of the project but may hinder publication.

question6c.value: We are only using two regression equations, so corrections are unnecessary.

question7c.value: Participants with specific missing data are deleted (see Methods - exclusion criteria)

question9c.value: -	There are no transformations that occur besides aggregation process. We will be cleaning the IATs separately. A cut off of 25 people per geographic area will be used. Then they will be combined with Census and FBI datasets, creating a data set with only counties or MSAs.

question10c.value:
Specifically, for this study’s variables, the solutions are as follows:
- Drop covariate if it is collinear - median income and violent crime the first to go
- If weapons and skin tone collinear, we can make a latent variable using Structural Equation Modeling and use this latent variable to predict Race IAT scores. 
-  If race is collinear with skin tone, we will drop the Skin Tone IAT.
- If race is collinear with weapons, we will drop the Weapons IAT. 
- If poverty and unemployment are too highly related, we can make them into a latent variable with only shared variance OR take out either (if either poverty or unemployment are colinear with more than 1 variable in the analysis) OR take out unemployment (not as conceptually related)

Rules I will be using to determine multicollinearity
- If any of the variables have a r > .8 with one another, they will be considered to be collinear. The offending variable will be removed or altered using the rules provided above. 
- The other clear indication of multicollinearity we will be looking for is a high R2 but insignificant coefficients. Multicollinearity will be assessed using multiple regression. Each independent variable will be regressed on all other independent variables. If both conditions below are satisfied, then the offending variable will be removed or altered using the rules above.
1) If the tolerance of a variable is close to 0
2) If any R2 of these regression analyses is over .64 (r = .82).

question1a.value:
H1. The Skin Tone IAT is a unique, significant predictor of the Race IAT at the context level: As Skin IAT scores increase, Race IAT scores increase.

H2. The Weapons IAT is a unique, significant predictor of the Race IAT at the context level: As Weapons IAT scores increase, Race IAT scores increase.

H3. Economic disadvantage is a unique, significant predictor of the Race IAT at the context level: As economic disadvantage increases, Race IAT scores also increase.

H4. Economic disadvantage is a moderator of the relationship between the Skin Tone IAT and the Race IAT such that the relationship (H1) is stronger at higher levels of economic disadvantage

H5. Economic disadvantage is a moderator of the relationship between the Weapons IAT and the Race IAT such that the relationship (H2) is stronger at higher levels of economic disadvantage.

question2a.value:
We suggest that when economic disparity is higher, the relationship between biases will be stronger (Race IAT and the Skin Tone or Weapons IAT). This is attributed to the increase in overlap of stereotypes and prejudices reinforcing existing biases, allowing these three biases to play off of and strengthen one another.

We expect the slope of the relationship between Race IAT and Skin Tone IAT to be greater for areas with higher (compared to lower) economic disparity. 

Similarly, we expect the slope of the relationship between Race IAT and Weapons IAT to be greater for areas with higher (compared to lower) economic disparity.
We expect the slope of the relationship between Race IAT and Skin Tone IAT to be greater for areas with higher (compared to lower) economic disparity. 
Similarly, we expect the slope of the relationship between Race IAT and Weapons IAT to be greater for areas with higher (compared to lower) economic disparity.

question3a.value: There is no manipulation occurring. This is a correlational design only.

question5a.value:
With the wide variety of stereotypes and biases that can affect African Americans, it is important to understand the contributions of these stereotypes and prejudice and how these biases relate to each other at the context level.

H1. Skin Tone IAT is a unique, significant predictor of the Race IAT at the context level.
        oThose with lighter skin, regardless of race, have better outcomes than those with darker skin in almost every area, including income, housing, and education (Hunter, 2007). 
        oResearch also shows that two features independently influence judgment of another’s race: facial features and skin tone (Blair et al., 2002). 
        oHowever, skin tone and race are often viewed as dependent upon one another: dark skinned faces are assumed to be African American (Stepanova & Strube, 2009). Stereotypes are often applied to those who are African American, dark skin, or have Afrocentric features without much colloquial differentiation between these groups (Blair et al., 2004; Blair et al., 2002; Stepanova & Strube, 2009). 
        oWe know Skin Tone and Race Bias are related, but their relationship and extent of their overlap is not addressed in the current literature.  
       oThere is no research that uses the Skin Tone IAT at the context level; understanding if and how these biases interact at the context-level is important in achieving a more comprehensive understanding of system-level bias. 

H2. The Weapons IAT is a unique, significant predictor of the Race IAT at the context level.
        oWeapons bias is often defined very broadly, such as when people claim to have seen a weapon when there is not one, most often with African American men (Payne, 2006, 2001).
        o Although the weapons bias can apply to anyone, the weapons bias is stronger for Blacks than other minorities (Sadler, Correll, Park, & Judd, 2012).
        oVarious stereotypes suggest that African Americans are dangerous and violent, with the Weapons bias being a consequence of broader biases (Oliver, 2003; Quillian & Pager, 2001). 
        oThe weapons bias has already been related to socially important outcomes at the context-level (Johnson & Chopik, 2018; Hehman, Flake & Calanchini, 2018). 
        oHowever, these studies use bias to predict social consequences (like disproportionate use of force by police) without an understanding on the composition of Race bias at the context-level.

H3. Economic disadvantage is a unique, significant predictor of the Race IAT at the context level 
        oEconomic disadvantage is highly related to race; often this is seen through the overrepresentation of minorities, and especially African Americans as poor and unemployed (Economic Policy Institute, 2014, 2018).
        oA more interesting way to look at the overrepresentation of minorities as poor is to analyze the overlap in stereotype content. Both the poor and African Americans as groups are associated with criminality, being irresponsible and lazy among other things (Carmona, 2011; Bobo & Kluegel 1993; Brigham, 1993). 

H4 and H5 - Economic Disadvantage as the moderator
         oThe next two hypotheses talk about the potential moderating effects of economic disadvantage. There are two mechanisms through which economic disadvantage may moderate relationships between other biases.
        o The presence of poverty or unemployment in the area might create a social threat through an increase in the negative societal effects of poverty, such as increased gun violence mortality [H5] (Males & Brown, 2014), and obesity rates (Kwarteng, Schulz, Mentz, Isreal, & White-Perkins, 2017). The threat of poverty's consequence might increase bias against those that are perceived to create these negative social outcomes.
        oThe second way that economic disadvantage might moderate the relationship between biases is through salience. When economic scarcity or disadvantage is salient, we tend to increase our use of heuristics, including skin tone [H4] and race bias (Chang, Krosch, & Cikara, 2016; Krosch & Armodio, 2014).
        oThese two mechanisms suggest economic disadvantage might moderate the relationship between related biases.

question6a.value: Only one prediction is made for each IV-DV combination.

question1c.value:
-	Only two regression equations will be run - one at the MSA level and one at the county level. 
-	Description of variables and their calculations are available on the methods page.

question2c.value: OLS Regression at the county and MSA level

question4c.value:
Median Income: This will control for areas that have lower absolute poverty or unemployment rates and allow us to access economic disparity, rather than poverty and unemployment in general. 
Violent Crime Rate: We want to measure weapons bias, without considerations of how seemingly legitimate that bias may be.

question5c.value:
-	We will use the typical .05 for null hypothesis testing. However, we will be focusing much more on effect sizes and the tightness of confidence intervals for understanding the implications of these variables. 
-	We will use Cohen's cut offs for small/medium/large effect sizes. However, they will be applied with some leniency in that implicit research is known for having smaller, but still meaningful effect sizes. Effect sizes of the main variables will also be compared to the covariates. If a variable of interest does not predict more than its covariate, then it may not be worth exploring.

H5. Economic disadvantage is a moderator of the relationship between the Weapons IAT and the Race IAT such that the relationship (H2) is stronger at higher levels of economic disadvantage.

With the wide variety of stereotypes and biases that can affect African Americans, it is important to understand the contributions of these stereotypes and prejudice and how these biases relate to each other at the context level.

H1. Skin Tone IAT is a unique, significant predictor of the Race IAT at the context level.

Stereotypes are often applied to those who are African American, dark skin, or have Afrocentric features without much colloquial differentiation between these groups (Blair et al., 2004; Blair et al., 2002; Stepanova & Strube, 2009). 
        oWe know Skin Tone and Race Bias are related, but their relationship and extent of their overlap is not addressed in the current literature.  
       oThere is no research that uses the Skin Tone IAT at the context level; understanding if and how these biases interact at the context-level is important in achieving a more comprehensive understanding of system-level bias. 

H2. The Weapons IAT is a unique, significant predictor of the Race IAT at the context level.
        oWeapons bias is often defined very broadly, such as when people claim to have seen a weapon when there is not one, most often with African American men (Payne, 2006, 2001).
        o Although the weapons bias can apply to anyone, the weapons bias is stronger for Blacks than other minorities (Sadler, Correll, Park, & Judd, 2012).

        oThe weapons bias has already been related to socially important outcomes at the context-level (Johnson & Chopik, 2018; Hehman, Flake & Calanchini, 2018).

        oA more interesting way to look at the overrepresentation of minorities as poor is to analyze the overlap in stereotype content. Both the poor and African Americans as groups are associated with criminality, being irresponsible and lazy among other things (Carmona, 2011; Bobo & Kluegel 1993; Brigham, 1993).

The threat of poverty's consequence might increase bias against those that are perceived to create these negative social outcomes.

When economic scarcity or disadvantage is salient, we tend to increase our use of heuristics, including skin tone [H4] and race bias (Chang, Krosch, & Cikara, 2016; Krosch & Armodio, 2014).
        oThese two mechanisms suggest economic disadvantage might moderate the relationship between related biases.

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Implicit association test. The IAT (Greenwald, McGhee, & Schwartz, 1998) is a computer-based reaction time test that provides information about the strength of associations between sets of social categories and evaluative or stereotypic concepts. All IATs have seven blocks but vary in what concepts they measure.
o	The first two blocks allow participants to practice using the “E” and “I” key to sort the two types of stimuli. The first block sorts the two social groups on two different sides of the screen. The second block teaches participants to sort the evaluative or stereotypic words on two different sides of the screen.
o	The third and fourth block combine the two pairs of concepts such that participants are matching one social group and one concept to the left side of the screen and the other combination of social group and concept to the right side of the screen. For example, in the Race IAT, participants might be asked to sort both “White” and “Good” stimuli on the right using the “I” key as well as sort both “Black” and “Bad” stimuli on the left using the “E” key. Block three includes 20 trials and block four includes 40 trials.
o	The fifth block is a training block where participants then practice switching the concepts, such that the word or picture on the right side of the screen is now being matched with the social category that was previously on the left side of the screen. The side associated with the racial categories changes such that “White” would now be sorted on the left side with the “E” key and “Black” would now be sorted on the right side with the “I” key. Participants are only sorting the social group in the fifth block to get used to the change in categorization.
o	The sixth and seventh block again combined the two pairs of concepts, but the opposite pairings are opposite to those of block three and four. For example, “White” would still be sorted on the left and “Black” would still be sorted on the right as well as sorting “Bad” on the left with the “E” key and sorting “Good” on the right with the “I” key. Block six includes 20 trials and block seven includes 40 trials.
o	Participant’s scores (called an IATD score) is calculated as the difference in reaction time between two pairings, divided by the standard deviation of the response latencies for these two blocks. In the Race IAT, this would be the degree to which participants more quickly pair “White” with “Good” than they pair “Black” with “Good”. Whether the first pairing is congruent (“White” and “Good”) or incongruent (“Black” and “Good”) is randomized between participants. It is important to recognize that the IAT captures two different sets of associations: associations about Black Americans and the associations about White Americans. While these might be independent, they are deeply connected. Indeed, many studies conceptualize prejudice as a preference for one group compared to a dispreference for the other group (Alter, Stern, Granot, & Balcetis, 2016). 
o	This study will be using the Race IAT, Weapons IAT, and Skin Tone IAT. Data will be downloaded from the Open Science Framework (Xu, Nosek, & Greenwald, 2014). All of the stimuli used for these IATs are available online (https://www.projectimplicit.net/nosek/stimuli/). 

Race IAT. The Race IAT compares the speed at which participants pair Black versus White faces with “Good” versus “Bad” words. This task typically shows a preference for White over Black faces.

Skin tone IAT. The Skin Tone IAT compares the speed at which the participants pair dark-skinned and light-skinned drawings of faces with “Good” and “Bad” words. This task typically shows a preference for light-skinned over dark-skinned faces.

Weapons IAT. The Weapons IAT compares the speed at which the participants pair Black versus White faces with weapons and harmless objects. This task typically shows an automatic association for Black Americans with weapons than harmless objects.

Economic disadvantage. Economic disadvantage at the MSA and county level will be assessed using multiple variables. 
o	Unemployment disparity. We will calculate relative rate of unemployment for each county and MSA from appropriate Census Data (U.S. Census Bureau, 2017b). We will first calculate the employment rate for each race in each area by dividing number of white citizens unemployed by the number of white citizens in that area and will repeat this process for Whites and Blacks for all counties and MSAs of interest. We will then divide the percentage of white citizens unemployed by the percentage of Black citizens unemployed to compute unemployment disparity.
o	Poverty disparity. The poverty rate will be taken from the Census Bureau (U.S. Census Bureau, 2017b). This measure includes people that are just above the poverty line, representing people with an income below the established poverty level for their state and family size. We will calculate relative rate of poverty for each county and MSA from appropriate Census Data (U.S. Census Bureau, 2017b). We will first calculate the poverty rate for each race in each area by dividing number of white citizens in below the poverty line by the number of white citizens in that area and will repeat this process for Whites and Blacks for all counties and MSAs of interest. We will then divide the percentage of white citizens under the poverty line by the percentage of Black citizens under the poverty line to compute poverty disparity.

Covariates. Including a few covariates will allow us to control for potential confounds. We will include two context-level covariates (median income and crime rate).	
o	Median income. Median income will be taken from the Census Bureau (U.S. Census Bureau, 2017a). The national median income of about $62,000 in 2018 (Guzman, 2019).
o	Crime rate. Crime rate will be calculated using the number of violent crimes as reported by the FBI Uniform Crime Reporting Program and Census Bureau (Federal Bureau of Investigation – Uniform Crime Reporting [FBI – UCR] 2015a, 2016; U.S. Census Bureau, 2017c). Included in the FBI’s calculation of violent crime are four offenses: murder and nonnegligent manslaughter, rape, robbery, and aggravated assault (FBI-UCR, 2015b). Crime rate will then be calculated by dividing the number of crimes committed in an area by the population of that area. Population estimates are calculated as part of the American Community Survey (ACS) for counties and MSAs (US Census Bureau, 2017c). Using FBI UCR and ACS data, we need to calculate the violent crime rate for each county and MSA of interest. We will divide the number of violent crimes by the number of people in each area. This will be calculated for each area of interest.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
-	Only two regression equations will be run - one at the MSA level and one at the county level. 
-	Description of variables and their calculations are available on the methods page.
OLS Regression at the county and MSA level

Median Income: This will control for areas that have lower absolute poverty or unemployment rates and allow us to access economic disparity, rather than poverty and unemployment in general. 
Violent Crime Rate: We want to measure weapons bias, without considerations of how seemingly legitimate that bias may be.

-	We will use the typical .05 for null hypothesis testing. However, we will be focusing much more on effect sizes and the tightness of confidence intervals for understanding the implications of these variables. 
-	We will use Cohen's cut offs for small/medium/large effect sizes. However, they will be applied with some leniency in that implicit research is known for having smaller, but still meaningful effect sizes. Effect sizes of the main variables will also be compared to the covariates. If a variable of interest does not predict more than its covariate, then it may not be worth exploring.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: -	Since this is all archival data, we do not control the pre-selection rules. While there are barriers (such as internet access) and incentives (such as understanding your bias) that might attract different people to the IAT, there are no explicit pre-selection rule. The same applies for the census and FBI UCR.

-	IAT data will be collected from Project Implicit. 
-	Violent crime rate will be collected from FBI UCR.
-	Median income and components of economic disadvantage will be collected from the Census.

-	The aggregation cut off of 25 comes from previous studies within our lab that suggest 25 produces a stable estimate and maximizes variability (Denzler, Regal, Gorenstein, Lim, & Devos, 2020). 
-	We are requiring each geographical area (both counties and MSAs) to have a minimum of 25 participants to ensure reliability of scores and validity of scores.
-	As far as number of counties or MSAs, this is determined indirectly by the aggregation process.
Since we are using all archival data, no data collection termination rule is necessary.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
-	For all three IATs, we will use data from 2004 to 2018 aggregated across years to estimate IATD scores for an area (both county and Metropolitan Statistical Area). 
-	We consolidate to a list of MSAs and counties that have at least 25 respondents for each IAT.
-	Data from other sources (census and FBI UCR) will be matched to MSAs and counties in which we have at least 25 participants. 
-	Due to the flexibility allotted to participants, there are a variety of standard exclusion criteria used to minimize noise from a variety of sources. 

-	a) Participants missing geographic data will also be removed. Only data from United States metropolitan areas will be analyzed. We consolidate to a list of MSAs and counties that have at least 25 respondents for each IAT. Data from other sources (census and FBI UCR) will be matched to MSAs and counties in which we have at least 25 participants. 
-	b) no manipulation checks or suspicion probes
-	c) No participants are removed for demographic reasons. Suspicious demographic information (age 107) is included. 
-	d) none?
-	e) Participants with 10% of their response times being faster than 300 milliseconds will be removed to improve the quality of the data; we assume that those with too many quick responses are not attending to the task at hand.

attributes.title: Relations in the neighborhood 2019 PL
attributes.description: Sociological analysis of neighborhoods in Poland in 2019

summary.value: The registration contains information about the research project "Relations in the neighborhood" implemented in 2019 in Poland. As part of the project, a database was made available (language - Polish) based on the CAWI and PAPI studies.

registration_responses.summary: The registration contains information about the research project "Relations in the neighborhood" implemented in 2019 in Poland. As part of the project, a database was made available (language - Polish) based on the CAWI and PAPI studies.

attributes.title: Comparative Effects of Rehabilitative Swallowing Exercises (RSE) and Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation in Stroke Patients: A Network Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials
attributes.description: Current evidence has demonstrated that either NMES or RSE and combination of NMES and RSE are effective in improving post-stroke dysphagia complications. Therefore, we will perform a network meta-analysis of comparative effects of NMES and RSE in improving post-stroke dysphagia complications.

attributes.title: Multiple accountabilities experiment
attributes.description: This study aims to experimentally investigate the effect of multiple accountabilities in the public sector on decision-making behavior. We specifically investigate the effect of number of forums and compatibility of forum demands on high effort and low effort coping strategies.

q1.value: Marija Aleksovska, Thomas Schillemans, Stephan Grimmelikhuijsen

q2.value:
H1a. Public sector actors will engage in more high effort coping strategies when faced with conflictual accountability demands than when faced with compatible accountability demands. 
H1b. Public sector actors will engage in more high effort coping strategies when faced with multiple accountability forums as opposed to a single one. 

H2a. Public sector actors will engage in more low effort coping strategies when faced with conflictual accountability demands than when faced with compatible accountability demands. 
H2b.  Public sector actors will engage in more low effort coping strategies when faced with multiple accountability forums as opposed to a single one. 

H3. The compatibility of forum demands will have a stronger effect on decision-making behavior than the number of accountability forums.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: The study has been performed using the Qualtrics tool, therefore the assignment of participants in one of the four groups has been done automatically.

question.value: Between subjects 2x2 design with each factor having two levels. First factor is the number of accountability forums (one or two). The second factor is compatibility of forum demands (compatible or conflicting).

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: We collected the data in February and March 2020. At the time of this registration, the data has not been downloaded nor in any way analyzed. We have only looked at the number of completed responses, in order to gain a rough estimate of the sample size.

question.value: The participants were recruited through six different distribution channels. These include two email lists, intranet invitation, newsletter invitation, invitation through a linkedin group, and an invitation through a knowledge sharing platform for regulators. All distribution channels were aimed to reach the same population - Dutch regulators. Thus, participants need to work (or have worked in the past) in a regulatory organization to be eligible to take part in the study. The participants were not paid for participating in the study.

q11.value: The data has been collected, however, since we have not looked into it nor cleaned it, we cannot give precisely the number of usable responses. On the basis of the number of completed responses, we estimate that the sample size would be somewhere between 245 and  275. Our unit of analysis is single-person response.

q12.value: We tried to reach as many Dutch regulators as we could given our resources.

question.value:
We manipulated two variables: 
1) Number of accountability forums: one forum or two forums.
2) Compatibility of accountability forum demands: compatible demands or conflicting demands.

Outcome measures: 
High effort coping strategies
- Decision-making effort  - measured as the time taken to make a decision; 
- Decision-making complexity - measured as coded integrative complexity in thinking on the basis of the written explanations of the decision; 
- Information search - measured through whether the participant selected an option to view more information before making a decision or not; 
Low effort coping strategies
- Asking for help - measured through two questions - How likely to ask colleague (1) / boss (2) for help. - 7 point scale. 
- Procrastination - measured through one question - How likely to help a colleague with an urgent case and postpone taking an action. - 7 point scale. 
- Buck-passing - measured through one question - How likely to transfer the responsibility for the case to a colleague if possible. - 7 point scale. 

Other measured variables (exploratory): 
- Affective states (challenged, stressed, bored, enthusiastic)
- Type of decision taken 

Manipulation checks: 
- Number of forums 
- Compatibility of forum demands

Background variables: 
- Recognizing the situation of multiple demands (5-point scale)
- Experience with supervision (4- point scale)
- Experience with working at the Youth and healthcare inspectorate
- Organization of employment
- Professional tenure
- Managerial role in work
- Supervisory role in work
- Frequency contact with clients (5 - point scale)
- Highest educational attainment
- Gender
- Birth year

The manipulation checks will be performed using an ANOVA test for the compatibility of forum demands and Chi-square test for the number of accountability forums.  

The main analysis will be performed using ANOVA for the continuous DVs (all except information search), and using Chi-square and Log-linear modeling for the categorical DV (information search).

q22.value: We will perform exploratory analysis on the effect of the two manipulated variables on affective states (challenged, stressed, bored, enthusiastic), as well as on the content of the decision the participants made (the measure they recommended to address the situation).

registration_responses.q1: Marija Aleksovska, Thomas Schillemans, Stephan Grimmelikhuijsen

H1a. Public sector actors will engage in more high effort coping strategies when faced with conflictual accountability demands than when faced with compatible accountability demands. 
H1b. Public sector actors will engage in more high effort coping strategies when faced with multiple accountability forums as opposed to a single one. 

H2a. Public sector actors will engage in more low effort coping strategies when faced with conflictual accountability demands than when faced with compatible accountability demands. 
H2b.  Public sector actors will engage in more low effort coping strategies when faced with multiple accountability forums as opposed to a single one. 

H3. The compatibility of forum demands will have a stronger effect on decision-making behavior than the number of accountability forums.

attributes.title: Misconceptions on Climate Mitigation Behavior
attributes.description: Truelove and Parks (2012) investigated misconceptions on behaviours related to climate-change among U.S. students. They found that participants overestimated the impact of littering, but underestimated the impact of meat consumption and adjusting the thermostat. It is unclear, how much knowledge the German public has about behaviours related to climate-change. This study investigates what a German sample knows about the impact of behaviours to mitigate global warming. Additionally, we investigate if there is a relationship between effectiveness knowledge and self-reported environmental behaviour. We are further interested in possible differences among different age groups, living places (city or countryside), and educational background.

q1.value: Daria Mundt, Rosalio Ochoa Saavedra, Marit Kristine List

q2.value:
1.	Misconceptions ~ Education level: We expect adult participants to have less misconceptions the higher their educational level (directional).
2.	Misconceptions ~ Personal involvement with the topic*educational level: We expect participants to have less misconceptions the more they are involved with global warming issues (directional). This effect will be stronger the higher their educational level (directional). 
3.	Misconceptions ~ Climate change sceptics: We expect participants to have less misconceptions when believing in an anthropogenic climate change (directional). 
4.	Misconceptions ~ Age*educational level: We expect participants to have more accurate knowledge the younger they are (directional). This effect will be stronger the higher the educational level (directional). 
5.	Environmental Behavior ~ Misconceptions*Environmental Optimism: We expect participants to behave more pro-environmentally the less misconceptions they have (directional). This effect will be stronger the lower their environmental optimism (directional).
6.	Environmental Behavior ~ Misconceptions*living place: The association of environmental behaviour and misconceptions is lower in rural areas compared to urban areas (directional).  
7.	Environmental Behavior ~ Misconceptions*SES: The association of environmental behaviour and misconceptions is lower the smaller the SES (directional).
8.	Misconceptions: Exploratory, we want to investigate if there are misconceptions that are prevalent across the whole sample and other misconceptions that are specific for climate change sceptics or/and certain age groups within our sample.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: There is no experimental treatment. Therefore, no blinding is needed. The real purpose of the study will not be revealed to participants.

question.value: We conduct a correlative online study.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The study will be conducted as an online-survey in German. Participants of this study will be people living in Germany with access to mobile devices and the ability to answer the online survey. For the recruitment, different communication tools will be used, like Facebook and Whatsapp-Groups. Different institutions will be contacted via e-mail and asked to share the survey-link with their workers. Moreover, contacts of the researchers will be contacted, personally approached and asked to forward the survey-link to their contacts. There will be no incentives for participants. 

The online-survey begins with asking for demographic data (living country, age, gender and educational background). Afterwards the term global warming will be defined to assure that every participant has the same concept of this issue. Participants will then be asked why climate changes (climate change sceptics). Now, they will be asked to rate prescribed behaviors regarding its impact on climate change (misconceptions on the effectiveness of mitigation behaviors). Afterwards, participants’ general environmental behavior will be assessed (environmental behavior). The following questions ask participants how much they believe specific environmental topics to get worse over time (environmental optimism); how much time they spend with the topic global warming in their daily and professional life (involvement with the climate change topic). In the end, we assess the place of residence (living place; at the moment and during childhood), migration background, and socioeconomic status (SES). 

The data collection is planned to take place from the 15/04/2020 till 31/07/2020.

q11.value: We aim a sample size of at least 300 participants.

q13.value: The data collection will be stopped at 31/07/2020.

question.value: There are no manipulated variables in the present study.

-	Age
-	Educational background:
o	For pupils: We will ask for grade and school type
o	For adults: highest educational achievement
-	Believe in anthropogenic climate change: 
o	Why do you believe climate changes? Answer options: human processes, natural processes, divine power, other
-	Misconceptions on the effectiveness of mitigation behaviors: Participants rate the effectiveness of a list of specific behaviors to mitigate global warming. 
o	7-point Likert-scale with 1 = not effective at all to 7 = very effective 
-	General environmental behavior: adapted GEB scale (Kaiser & Wilson, 2000, 2004) 
-	Environmental optimism (OECD, 2009, 2017): 
o	Question: Do you believe the following environmental problems to improve or to get worse in the upcoming 20 years? 
o	Problems: The increase of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere; Nuclear waste; clearing forests for other land use; Air pollution; Extinction of plants and animals; Water shortage; Energy shortage; Global warming; food shortage; drought; Long-lasting hot spells; wildfires
o	3-point Likert-scale with 1 = improves; 2 = stays the same; 3 = gets worse
-	Involvement with the topic global warming in every day and professional life:
o	Question1: How often are you dealing with the topic climate change in your daily and professional life?
o	5-point Likert-scale with 1 = never; 3 = from time to time; 5 = very often
-	Living place (current and during childhood)
o	<2,000 inhabitants
o	2,000-5,000 inhabitants
o	5,000-10,000 inhabitants
o	10,000-20,000 inhabitants
o	20,000-50,000 inhabitants
o	50,000-100,000 inhabitants
o	100,000-500,000 inhabitants
o	>500,000 inhabitants
-	Socioeconomic status: 
o	We assess the belongings according to PISA (OECD 2009, 2012, 2014, 2017)

First, the frequency and type of misconceptions will be analyzed descriptively. Therefore, we will calculate to what extent misconceptions on specific behaviors are present in the sample (in percentage). 
To investigate relationships with misconceptions, we will run a stepwise multiple regression with the number of misconceptions as criterion and age, education level, SES, current living place, climate change sceptics and personal involvement as predictors. We are analyzing the following main effect terms: Educational level (H1); personal involvement (H2); climate change sceptics (H3), Age (H4). Moreover, the following interaction terms will be analyzed: Educational level*personal involvement (H2) and age*educational level (H4).
To investigate the relationship of misconceptions and environmental behaviour, we will run a stepwise multiple regression with environmental behaviour as criterion. As predictors we will include the amount of misconceptions, environmental optimism, SES, current living place. We are analyzing the following main effect terms: misconceptions (H5), environmental optimism (H5), living space (H6), SES (H7). Moreover, the following interaction terms will be analyzed: misconceptions*environmental optimism (H5), misconceptions*living space (H6), misconceptions*SES (H7)

q19.value: To make inferences a p-value of .05 will be used.

q23.value:
Kaiser, F. G., & Wilson, M. (2000). Assessing people ‘s general ecological behavior: A cross-cultural measure. Journal of Applied Social Psychology, 30, 952-978.
Kaiser, F. G., & Wilson, M. (2004). Goal-directed conservation behavior: The specific composition of a general performance. Personality and Individual Differences, 36, 1531-1544.
Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development [OECD] (2009). PISA 2006 Technical Report. Paris, F: OECD.
OECD (2012). PISA 2012 Technical Report. Paris, F: OECD.	
OECD (2014). PISA 2012 Technical Report. Paris, F: OECD.
OECD (2017). PISA 2015 Technical Report. Paris, F: OECD.
Truelove, H. B., & Parks, C. (2012). Perceptions of behaviors that cause and mitigate global warming and intentions to perform these behaviors. Journal of Environmental Psychology, 32, 246–259.

4.	Misconceptions ~ Age*educational level: We expect participants to have more accurate knowledge the younger they are (directional). This effect will be stronger the higher the educational level (directional). 
5.	Environmental Behavior ~ Misconceptions*Environmental Optimism: We expect participants to behave more pro-environmentally the less misconceptions they have (directional). This effect will be stronger the lower their environmental optimism (directional).
6.	Environmental Behavior ~ Misconceptions*living place: The association of environmental behaviour and misconceptions is lower in rural areas compared to urban areas (directional).

8.	Misconceptions: Exploratory, we want to investigate if there are misconceptions that are prevalent across the whole sample and other misconceptions that are specific for climate change sceptics or/and certain age groups within our sample.

To investigate relationships with misconceptions, we will run a stepwise multiple regression with the number of misconceptions as criterion and age, education level, SES, current living place, climate change sceptics and personal involvement as predictors. We are analyzing the following main effect terms: Educational level (H1); personal involvement (H2); climate change sceptics (H3), Age (H4). Moreover, the following interaction terms will be analyzed: Educational level*personal involvement (H2) and age*educational level (H4).
To investigate the relationship of misconceptions and environmental behaviour, we will run a stepwise multiple regression with environmental behaviour as criterion. As predictors we will include the amount of misconceptions, environmental optimism, SES, current living place. We are analyzing the following main effect terms: misconceptions (H5), environmental optimism (H5), living space (H6), SES (H7). Moreover, the following interaction terms will be analyzed: misconceptions*environmental optimism (H5), misconceptions*living space (H6), misconceptions*SES (H7)

attributes.title: The influence of rhythm on short-term memory for serial order (data)
attributes.description: This repository contains the raw data, the data processing scripts, and the statistical analyses output files from the pre-registered study entitled "The influence of rhythm on short-term memory for serial order" (see https://osf.io/s3tvh, for the pre-registered protocol and material). The repository also contains the manuscript accepted for publication indicating changes made relative to the content that received an in-principle acceptance.

The repository also contains the manuscript accepted for publication indicating changes made relative to the content that received an in-principle acceptance.

The repository also contains the manuscript accepted for publication indicating changes made relative to the content that received an in-principle acceptance.

attributes.title: Expertise and Public Policy Support
attributes.description: This study examines the effect of bureaucratic expertise on policy support.

q2.value:
H1a: Expert information will have a positive effect on policy support. 

H1b: Expert information will have a stronger effect on policy support for left leaning participants than for right leaning participants.

H2a: Participants will be more likely to support the policy proposed by public sector scientists than private sector scientists.

H2b: The effect of the public sector scientist cue on policy support will be stronger for left leaning participants when compared to right leaning participants.

H3: For both public sector and private sector source cues, the positive effect of the expert source cue will be weaker as information increases.

H4a: Right-leaning respondents will be less likely to support the proposed policy and will discuss more partisan related factors as reasons why.

H4b: The negative relationship between having right-leaning political beliefs and policy support will strengthen as participants are exposed to more policy information.

H5: As information increases, individuals' explanation of what the policy aims to do will become more negative.

H6: As information increases, individuals will use more partisan language to explain what the policy aims to do.

H7: Left leaning participants exposed to the government scientist cue will have higher levels of trust in scientists than those exposed to the private sector scientist cue.

H8: Right leaning participants exposed to the government scientist cue will have lower levels of trust in scientists than those exposed to the private sector scientist cue. 

H8a: Participants exposed to more policy information cue will have lower levels of trust in scientists than those exposed to less policy information.

H8b: This effect will be strongest for right-leaning participants.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects 2 (private sector versus public sector scientist) by 3 (low policy information, medium policy information, high policy information exposure) factorial design with two baselines: 1) no sector cue is used, and 2) no expertise cue is used. See attachment for more details.

q7.value: Individual participants will be randomly assigned to a treatment group using a random number generator program provided by the survey software.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from Amazon's mechanical turk using TurkPrime. Participants will be paid at a rate roughly equivalent to $10 per hour. Sampling criteria include approval ratings (greater than 85%) and number of hits (greater
than 500).

q11.value: Based upon a power analysis using the 'easypower' R package, we estimate needed roughly 200 participants per treatment group. We need a total of 1400 usable responses. Because not all responses we receive will be usable, we aim to recruit 2000 participants.

question.value:
Expertise: Expert cue is provided or not.
Sector expertise: Participants are told the scientists are from the private sector or public sector.

Level of information: there are three levels - low (1 piece of policy information), medium (2 pieces of policy information), or high (3 pieces of policy information)

We primarily rely on close and open ended responses to measure attitudes toward the policy and policy support.

Close-ended items:
Policy support:
     Willingness to pay framework to evaluate policy support. (how much of your salary would 
     you pay in taxes for this policy (between 0 and 5%))

    How much do you support this policy (0 = not at all, 10 = a great deal)

Trust in scientists:

    We use a composite scale adapted from Grimmelikhuijsen and Knies (2017) Please refer to the attachment for more information.

We plan to use ANOVA (including planned contrasts), Bayesian ANOVA, OLS regression to test for differences between treatment groups. We will use structural topic models, sentiment analysis, and regularized logistic regression to analyze the open ended item.

H7: Left leaning participants exposed to the government scientist cue will have higher levels of trust in scientists than those exposed to the private sector scientist cue.

H8b: This effect will be strongest for right-leaning participants.
